Award.AwardTitle: Robust and Relevant Model Evaluation: Principles and Techniques for Handling Weak Prior Information and Contaminated Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research concerns the development of innovative model comparison and model evaluation methods that focus on the most relevant features of the data and that are robust to deficiencies of model and data. The advent of modern, automated technology for data collection and of cheap, near-boundless storage capacity provides access to a previously undreamt wealth of data. The parallel development of sophisticated models which allow one to combine many sources of information and the computational strategies and horsepower which allow one to fit the models would seem to facilitate near-perfect decision-making. However, the wealth of data aggravates the problems caused by data contamination, and the complexity of model aggravates the difficulty of specifying the prior on the parameters. Handling data contamination and constructing methods robust to the lack of prior information pose fundamental statistical challenges. In this project, the investigators illustrate the deficiency of the current leading model evaluation/model comparison methods, and then propose a set of new tools to alleviate the problems. The proposed research consists of the following two specific aims. 1. To develop reliable methods for Bayesian model comparison when prior information is lacking. The common practices of using an improper noninformative prior distribution or a vague proper prior distribution are effective in estimation, however they break down for Bayesian hypothesis testing problems where model choice is sensitive to details of the prior distribution. To tackle this difficulty, the investigators propose a remedy, the calibrated Bayes factor. The calibrated Bayes factor does not need extensive subjective evaluation, yields an analysis that better mimics the performance of the Bayes factor under a ''reasonable default'' prior, and is widely applicable in a large variety of model comparison problems. 2. To develop robust methods for model evaluation and model fitting in the presence of contaminated data. Contaminated data comes in many forms, including observations potentially from recording mistakes or from irrelevant populations. The contaminating process might be unstable, which makes standard statistical modeling infeasible. For model fitting, this project develops and implements restricted-likelihood, which leads to estimation strategies that focus on the most relevant features of the data and that are robust to ''bad data''. For model evaluation, this project develops an adaptive loss (scoring) paradigm for cross-validation, which produces robust results and yields superior finite-sample performance by stabilizing the evaluation.

Model evaluation and model comparison are used on a daily basis in both scientific and corporate decision-making settings. These techniques help researchers judge which theory best describes the phenomenon, help health professionals identify which risk factors are related to disease incidence, and help corporate managers decide which business strategy results in increased sales or better customer retention. However, most of the current model evaluation and model comparison methods neglect deficiencies in data or suffer from the lack of parameter information. The proposed research provides powerful methodological tools for robust model preference, model evaluation, and model fitting in these difficult situations. It can help people in various fields better extract information from massive data sets, and thus optimize their decision making. Specific applications in health studies, psychological experiments and machine learning will proceed along with development of the new methodology. The general methodology is also applicable to many other scientific and technical areas, such as genomics, climatology, and economics, where large data sets are collected and robust model evaluation is desirable. The investigators are well-positioned to disseminate the project's results. They have been actively involved in research groups at the intersection of Statistics and the social sciences, engineering/computer science, and marketing. They are also key members of a joint industry-university center dedicated to provide and disseminate research relevant to the insurance industry. Results from this project will be spread to other communities through the investigators' interactions with these groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project has taken aim at issues driven by the changing nature of data.  Data sets are now massive, but massive is not just “more of the same”.  Instead, data is richer, with many more measurements taken on each case, and with greater variety in the types of measurements that are taken.  Data sets are often fragmented, with multiple data sets needed to solve a problem.  The combination of automated data capture and cheap storage has led to exponential growth in the amount of data available to understand the world and to make decisions.  These big data sets comprise the data bases found throughout corporations and government. 

The wealth of available data provides a tremendous amount of information, and at first glance might seem to answer all questions.  However, two features downgrade the quality of purely data-based decisions.  First, all large data sets are vulnerable to poor data quality—much of the data is observational, self-reported, or recorded imperfectly.  Second, the very richness of the data encourages one to ask questions that stretch the limits of the data.  Rather than purely data-driven decisions, data-and-model-driven decisions perform best. 

The project addressed data quality by creating a framework, called Bayesian restricted likelihood, under which data of modest quality can be combined with a model.  The framework makes use of the data through insufficient summary statistics, combining this information with the model using Bayesian techniques.  Computational and theoretical results provide the details needed to implement these methods in a wide variety of problems, including those based on regression and the linear model.  The methods are fully compatible with hierarchical Bayesian models, allowing one to combine information from multiple data sets to answer a single question. 

The project addressed the richness of data by providing novel means of model comparison and evaluation via the calibrated Bayes factor.  Informative data, particularly if observational rather than experimental, naturally generate hypotheses which may or may not explain the observed patterns.  Technical results allow one to unify Bayesian methods designed for estimation with those designed for model comparison.  This leads to a single, comprehensive analysis which addresses hypotheses (captured as models) through model comparison and also addresses a suite of predictive questions which rely on both models and parameters within the models. 

The effort in this project has been directed toward high-dimensional and infinite-dimensional models.  In keeping with the changing nature of data, the focus has been on dimension reduction when data do not conform to a standard model, either due to lack of quality of due to different measurement types.  Dimension reduction occurs through the use of robust summaries where a standard model replaces a much more complicated model (Bayesian restricted likelihood), through the use of standard prior distributions with adjustment to the usual model comparison (calibrated Bayes factor), and through innovative statistical learning techniques (principal components for non-normal data).  

 

Broader Impacts

The project has had a substantial impact on the development of human resources.  Eleven students have earned their PhDs in conjunction with this project.  Upon graduation, these students moved on to positions in industry, at national laboratories, and in academics, with most pursuing careers as applied statisticians / data scientists in United States corporations.  A further nine students are currently working with the PIs on their PhD dissertations.  These students are expected to graduate within the next several years.  The placement of these graduates has increased the flow of information between academic and corporate America. 

Several researchers have spent extended amounts of time at The Ohio State University to work with the PIs.  These include visitors from leading institutions in Japan and China.  Briefer collaborations and collaboration-at-a-distance have occurred with a considerable number of research partners.  This collaborative work has been beneficial to the careers of all involved and has enhanced the connections between various universities as well as between the PIs and non-academic institutions.  A sizeable fraction of the project has operated at the intersection of various disciplines, notably the health sciences, computer science, and psychology.  This interdisciplinary work has strengthened the connections between researchers in these disciplines and has exposed students and other early-career scientists to work and to perspectives that stretch them well beyond traditional disciplinary training. 

Several corporations and government agencies have expressed interest in the results arising from this project.  The PIs have given short courses and talks at companies in the pharmaceutical industry where the results may be applied in the process of drug development and in the insurance agency where the results may be applied to improve internal business decisions.  The PIs have also presented short courses internationally to diverse audiences consisting of academics and others.  Copies of publications have been requested by and passed along to members of government agencies (e.g., the Food and Drug Administration, the Federal Reserve).
